instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi all,

I have here a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with minor liquid damage around <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> area. Nobody touched it before, that's good but found more than 1 problem. I was not getting 20v on the USB amp meter and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was jumping up and down, couldn't get a reading.

Found that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was shorted by <CAPACITOR>C9501</CAPACITOR>. Removed that cap and got a nice ppbus and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. 

Then noticed <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> is 2,5ohm to ground. Hoped for a bad <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> but even after removing that still short. After injecting 2v into rail found heat was coming from <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> which is only nand chip on this left top and bottom side (there are in total of 5 nand chips). 

I was wondering, I have another donor board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> witch exact same volume of nand chips. Can I suffice by only switching <CHIP>U8600</CHIP>. I read a few times that you always have to change them with sets, but these look exactly the same... 

Please advice. Thxs

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Give it a try, it may work in this case.
Once <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> is removed compare diode mode readings on its power rail with the value on the other board; after removing <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> there too.
